author: Dr. Sarah Johnson (ED)
note_text:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
65 y/o male with severe COPD (FEV1 32% predicted), on home O2 2L. Presents with 2 days of worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production (yellow-green). Reports inability to complete sentences. 40 pack-year smoking history, quit 5 years ago.

ED COURSE:
Patient in severe respiratory distress on arrival, using accessory muscles. SpO2 78% on RA, placed on NRB with minimal improvement. ABG shows acute on chronic respiratory acidosis (pH 7.31, pCO2 58). Started on BiPAP 12/5 with improvement in work of breathing and sats to 92%.

MEDICAL DECISION MAKING:
Severe COPD exacerbation with acute hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure.

Severity indicators:
1. Acute respiratory failure requiring BiPAP
2. ABG showing respiratory acidosis
3. Elevated procalcitonin suggesting bacterial infection
4. Tachypnea (RR 32) and accessory muscle use
5. Failed to maintain oxygenation on simple O2

PLAN:
Admit to ICU (Inpatient).
Continue BiPAP, may need intubation if worsens.
IV Solumedrol, nebulizers Q4H.
IV antibiotics (Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin) for presumed bacterial trigger.
Expected stay 4-7 days.
